comments.commentBody:
No, he isn't handsome: he looks (and sounds) exactly like the computer-animated corporate villain in a cartoon movie about environmental destruction. And it's offensive to compare his thick-skinned quips about wealth to those of Candidate Obama, whose biggest drawback in relating to us farmers was that he's a city kid elected from an agribusiness state, and had limited information from lousy advisers.

But Romney, so far from being embarrassed by his wealth, brought up not to mention it, or "tongue-tied" about it, is glib, that's what he is is. And like most of the corporate villains among us, he thinks he's relating, and it falls flat.

Unfortunately Deb already got hooked by the class warefare, evil 1% stole my $ sales pitch. All the GOP candidates and Obama are in the 1% (mabye not Santorum but Im sure he will be coming out with a horrible book soon to join the club). If you were getting an operation would you want an experienced, accomplished surgeon or someone you could relate to?

Every time Romney commits one of his "gaffes', it's simply the truth coming out quite by accident.  He has not one clue about the 99%.  I don't care how well his handlers try to write the appropriate script for him to follow, it still comes across as an act - because it is.  Hopefully, most of us realize a sales pitch when we hear one.  I do and I'm not buying for a second - I find it offensive.  And by the way, I don't think he's good looking at all.

rh, no need to clap, my dear fellow, as single a-PLOD will prove sufficient!

Captive Midnight
aka WHH

What if the employers' religious beliefs forbid transfusions, transplants or even hospitalization care as we know it? Can they block employees from those procedures, even if state law requires coverage? The position of the RC Church is laughable except its is designed to help the GOP score points against Obama.
There are many states that require all health insurance policies cover contraception, abortions and even in-vitro fertilization. Religious groups have lost every suit they brought against states when challenging their inclusive insurance coverage. Imagine If an employer could deny transfusions because of his religious views. If the RC Church is successful why not challenge other insurance laws as anti-religious. A single payer health care system would have avoided all of this mess.

aaaa, that's aaaadorable!

WHH

Rudy, I live in Yamaguchi Prefecture near Hiroshima. At the time of the disaster, I DID evacuate out of Japan. I have enough connections in the US military & science communities to piece together the worst-case scenario, and realized that both US & Japanese governments were not being honest. I also calculated that if I kept my family here & the need for evacuation became evident, by then it would be too late to get out. There was just no way I would have been able by then to get my family out of harm's way.

I was somewhat ridiculed by the expat community who lives near me for leaving when no one else was. Yet reports like this confirm that I did the right thing. The margin between safety & utter disaster was razor-thin; I'm surprised at how few people in the general population figured this out for themselves.

I don't know what news programs you were watching, but I thought the Japanese news coverage was about as good as can be expected under the circumstances. They seemed to be trying their level best to give useful information, and certainly didn't seem to be "toeing the line" as has often been the accusation.

When all this was happening, I spent like 23 hours a day under the kotatsu watching TV (not much else to do...), and the news programs (it was all news, all day, on Japanese TV at that point) seemed to be doing their best. The "experts" they trotted out (mostly I remember academics) had various takes, but a typical report was something like "we don't have enough information, it could be very bad; here's an an explanation of what we do know and what possible things could happen ... <followed by a somewhat technical explanation of the reactor and possible outcomes>". By and large I'd say the tone seemed "pessimistic but realistic." They clearly wanted to tell people what was really happening, but also tried to avoid sensationalizing.

This is in stark contrast with the blatant tone of unreasoned panic in the western media, which was a constant drumbeat of "OMG WE'RE ALL GONNA DIE!!1!". Even in hindsight, knowing things were even worse than they appeared at the time, the reaction of the western media was far less responsible.

Probably the Japanese nuclear establishment should have been more forthcoming, and there is legitimate reason for criticism there.
Atheists don't have to believe crazy things to prove anything to anybody.

Yes, definitely the atheists and lefties who give into passions, not Church Lady Rick ranting about Satan and dangers of sex when you not making babies,Newtie talking up the loonar colony, or tap-dancing Mittens and the magic underwear.
High falootin' straw man.

"Though she agreed with the warning, she said, 'I wouldn’t say it at work.'”

Me thinks that might be part of the problem! How can one genuinely hold a world view which demands a particular set of values, but casually acquiesce in an antithetical view which is offensive to the moral and ethical imperatives of conscience? The secularist, no less than the religious man, presumes to relegate to the realm of frivilty convictions which stand in opposition to his own. This despite the fact that his own are built upon a foundation no less (and in most instances more) dependant upon faith and the imposition of dogma than those of the sincerly devout. Athiests, skeptics, and agnostics consistently adhere to a self-serving world view which demands from them nothing more noble or productive than a surrender to passion, unstable emotion, momentary whim, or primal appetite. They then insultingly presume an air of enlightenment, ridiculing those who genuinely seek after a moral existence. These "enlightened ones" certainly have no qualms when it comes to the expression of their world view. Can one imagine, in contemporary American society, the dedicated imbiber who conceals his drunken proclivities for the sake of the devout coworker, or the aborting woman who, out of respect for devoted fathers, holds only silently to her feminist agenda. Hardly! It is flagrantly obnoxious to suggest that only secular views may legitimately sally forth into the public arena.

Not sure I understand the distinction. Most themes have nothing to do with the "solving" of the puzzle, if by solving you mean finding answers to clues until the grid is completed.

Themes are revealed. Sometimes they take a little work to "get." Sometimes, like today, they're hidden in plain sight.

Two things I would say are different about this kind of puzzle. One, it has essentially one payoff, unlike many puzzles that have a handful of theme answers. Is that enough? Absolutely. It was a good "a-ha" for me. Two, it's self-referential, with a theme about itself, not something external. For some reason these kind of puzzles often draw complaints ("mere constructor stunts"), as if there's something not legit about it. But this sort of thing has a long tradition in other forms (see Magritte's "This is not a pipe" or Looney Tunes's "Duck Amuck," to cite just two examples of many), so why not crosswords?

I think the key for any puzzle is not how it's made, but does it work. This one certainly did for me.

[I seem to be running out of space. I'll be back for part 2.]

Travis writes:

"You don't think it's wrong that the majority of the Syrian people are Sunni, while the Assad regime, the people in control of the country, are mostly Alawi Shias?"

Does it bother you that Obama is black and most of the US is white? Or are you satisfied because he was elected? What should upset you is that Assad was not.

Judy,

"he should have said that he would not be a candidate under the revised constitution."

Why? My impression (and I read largely liberal Western media) is that Assad has the support of most Syrians. Why should they not get a chance to elect him in a fair election under a new constitution? Who are we to tell them who can run and who can't?

Grim Reaper,

A lot of blood has been shed and a lot of corpses have piled up. The West is a force that can work in the interest of humanitarians to put a halt to bloodshed, conflicts of interest aside.

What you say is correct. But in addition, Syria lies on a  trade route through which various Asian Mafia to transport its cargo. Note, China, Russia, many Arab nations are part of Asia, and each have their own Mafia rings. These forces, of which Hezbollah is a minor element, have are now dominating the streets, and have taken over the protests. They have coopted the protestors wish for peace, for security and prosperity.

[Part 2]

The key for a puzzle like this, imo, is that the clues don't give away the trick. The solver needs to find the theme by what's revealed in the grid, not by sensing something unusual in the clues. I thought this puzzle did a superb job on that score. I had barely noticed the 1A clue, "Norwegian city," for OSLO, which seemed a bit matter-of-fact at the start, but that was the last I gave the cluing any thought till the theme was revealed later. Looking back, I'd say the only sign of strain you might find is in the clues for the 15s. Minor stuff. I don't see any other clues that would be redone if not for the theme.

The "Less" and MORE combination at 38A brought to mind one of the Oscar winners from last night, the animated short "The Fantastic Flying Books of Mr. Morris Lessmore." Book lovers might enjoy:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Adzywe9xeIU

Deb, Thanks so much for providing the nostalgic clip of Peter, Paul and Mary, singing one of their greatest hits, I must say it came in quite Hannalee!

Howie

It's completely off-track to assert that filler words are a sign of poor verbal skills. These words are used by young women who are often engaged in rapid-fire conversations with their peers, and whose social success is almost completely dependent on their verbal abilities. Guys are allowed to say what they mean, but girls are expected to find just the right words and tone of voice to avoid appearing the least bit aggressive. Filler words allow the speaker to keep from being interrupted while they search for the perfect word to use. Therefore, in a social setting, they are a valuable tool.

comments.userLocation: Living On the Road in America

comments.commentBody: Karolina, ease off the defensiveness. *Of course* we're judged on how we speak! Not entirely, but it certainly makes sense, especially when interacting with someone we don't know well and there's not much else to go on. Like it or not, this speech pattern makes you sound less intelligent than you are, and it mars your "interesting comments on academic subjects." I hope you can stop relying on this verbal tic. It's simply a habit that can be broken.

I'm sorry but "like" has always struck me as a marker for a low-performing mind.  When you have poor verbals skills and a weak vocabulary, it gets hard for you to describe events in an intelligible way.  So you're reduced to play-acting them out, sort of like a first-grader.
So if we truly find this sound annoying, then we're "Edwin Newmans?"   Can't we truly be annoyed by a truly annoying sound?

Do you have any links to source material on the Scotch-Irish, and the Australian/Pacific roots of Western American speech? And I agree with other comments on being annoyed at these new trends, but as Mr. Ranson stated, it's "part of the living process of our language".

I love when the Times does an article on Sociolinguistics so I can find out where all my old friends are now.

There is an only slightly over stated theory which says that women create culture and that language is the mechanism by which they create it.

Young women are, as mentioned, linguistically advanced, that is the changes reflected in their speech anticipate changes that will soon be reflected in language generally. In the 1980s Val Girl dialect became prominent in the speech of young women on the West Coast. This dialect did include Australian and Pacific elements, as stated, but was composed primarily of exaggerations of elements typical of Western American English, which ultimately had their roots in Scotch-Irish dialect. Many of these features have now spread through American English generally. This in turn reflects the increased cultural importance of the West Coast and especially California in American society.

Times readers then have two choices, you can go all Edwin Newman and make fun of innovation, or you can pay attention to the innovation and be a part of the living process of our language.
Can't imagine Sylvia Poggioli or Nina Totenberg uptalking or frying -  people you can take seriously.

I heard a female newsreader on WNYC referring to Manhattan as Manha'en. I wrote to complain about it—I mean, there are two ts there and she couldn't pronounce one of them? Subsequently, a different female, reading the list of sponsors, started pronouncing every t as if there were six of them—e.g., "importtttttantttttt."

I'm a progressive, but it seems people's speech and thoughts used to be so much more precise. I think it's because the bases of language—Latin, Greek, for example—are no longer part of the high school curriculum. Words have lost their precision and have to be supported with vocal histrionics.

@edwcorey- "it seems people's speech and thoughts used to be so much more precise"

I guarantee that never happened. There was never any golden age when everyone spoke "precisely".

If you study the speech of any population, only a small percentage of people speak in the "standard" or "high class" dialect in their everyday lives. For example: in this country, that's generally considered to be Midwestern/TV broadcaster English. (Think Tom Brokaw). In the UK, that would be "received pronunciation" (as spoken by the royal family). The vast majority of people in any country speak non-standard dialects- that is, they use sounds, syntax, intonation, etc., that differ from the "high-class" dialect.

The fact is that language changes constantly, and always will. The older generation invariably notices that the younger generation speaks a bit differently,and it sounds newfangled and off-putting to them. But it's not less precise- it's just different than what they're used to. 'Twas ever thus.
I would like to hear or read something about some of the voices on NPR. There are some very interesting ones on there, mostly women, that I'm curious as to how to categorize them.

It's that gravelly low sounding voice that you hear,as if the person who is talking did not take in enough breath to complete the intended words they want to speak so as they progress in their commentary the sounds become brittle and break apart as if they are recovering from a terrible throat cold.  It's really an ugly sound but if you listen to most any 18 to 24 year-old you'll hear it, or so it seems.
"Spreading herpes" is a pretty, um, picturesque analogy. Though I would agree that these vocal stylings are spreading in a viral fashion.

"Deserve credit" makes it sound as if this is something to be PROUD of. What nonsense. The lower register, "uptalk", stretching out the last syllable of a phrase, talking percussively, overuse of like/"ya know" are all affectations that I find as annoying, pretentious, and narcissistic/smug (nudge nudge, wink wink, he he he, he he he) as my own generation's affectations (groovy, can you dig it). This "style" is as much a substitute for substance as "style" was in my day, and it gets in the way of taking "the affected" seriously: take away the "style" and what is left? It's not a positive "trend", and being widespread doesn't make it so. It's sort of like spreading herpes.

Incidentally: "bitchin" and "like" go back at least to the 1970s or 1960s.
Dr. Liberman was, like, seriously suggesting that GWB was not insecure. That, I mean, is, like, totally insane.

... “and nobody ever said, ‘Oh, that G.W.B. is so insecure, just like a young girl.’ ”  Well, actually, we all did say that about GWB. Wasn't his insecurity thoroughly obvious? The uptalk just confirmed what we already knew.
@WHH: My comments practically fly off the page when spring comes around! :) sorry of my earlier comment posted at 10.54 was banal
If, not of!

I found the story inspiring, its picture of child-parent bonding heartwarming.  Most of us labor at jobs which drift beyond the consciousness of our children, leaving us separated in important ways even as we approach extinction.  The risks of a military life are major, and I am moved that an effort can be made by the military to bridge the gulf of time and space in some military families.
OMG ! The attendances were a lot lower than Mitt 13.9% tax rate.  No wonder, Mitt wants to cut his tax rate further.
